speaker: chana joffe-walt
utterance: She says her symptoms come and go, and she's just not confident she could hold down a full time job. So she doesn't want to do anything that can threaten a dependable, secure monthly check. That is incredibly valuable to her. Although, when she talks about her experience working as a tutor, sounds like that was pretty valuable too.

speaker: talia mcfadden
utterance: Most of my students said, I trust you. And I felt like-- I felt appreciated, you know. Sometimes the parents would say that the kid wouldn't stop talking about me.

speaker: chana joffe-walt
utterance: So that must have been hard to give that up.

speaker: talia mcfadden
utterance: Yeah. Because it kind of gave me a sense of wanting to be and wanting to live.

speaker: chana joffe-walt
utterance: It gave you a sense of wanting to be and wanting to live?

speaker: talia mcfadden
utterance: Yeah, because I just feel like I don't belong. Like I'm not helping to make things better.

speaker: chana joffe-walt
utterance: The idea that we, as a society, should offer support to disabled children living in poverty, I haven't taken a survey or anything, but I'm guessing a large majority of Americans would be in favor of that in some form. We'd have a hard time agreeing exactly how we want to offer support. But I think there are some basic things we all agree on. Kids should be encouraged to go to school. Kids should want to do well in school. Parents should want their kids to do well in school. Kids should be confident their parents can provide for them, regardless of how they do in school. And the goal should always be for children to become more and more independent as they grow older, and, if possible, support themselves, somewhere around the age of 18.

speaker: chana joffe-walt
utterance: This program stands in opposition to every one of these aims.

speaker: chana joffe-walt
utterance: So somewhere around 30 years ago, the economy started changing in some important ways. There are now millions of Americans who do not have the education or the skills for the current economy. And this does not seem temporary.

speaker: chana joffe-walt
utterance: Politicians certainly pay lip service to this problem during election cycles and such. But American leaders have not sat down and said, look, things have fundamentally changed. What are we going to do for these people? We need a plan.

speaker: chana joffe-walt
utterance: In the meantime, the disability programs have become the default plan. Programs that, along with the associated health care, cost about $260 billion a year. And I know this is obvious, but a quarter trillion dollars? That's a lot of money. That's eight times more than we spend on welfare. In fact, it is more than we spend on welfare, food stamps, the school lunch program, and subsidized housing combined. A lot more.

speaker: chana joffe-walt
utterance: Think for a minute of what we could do with a quarter trillion dollars. We could decide what we want is to expand welfare payments or food stamps. We could decide that the best plan is just to hand out cash to every out of work American. Or we could decide not to spend the money. Let everybody pay less in taxes. There are options. We just never made a decision.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: Chana Joffe-Walt. She's with Planet  Money, which is a co-production of our program and NPR News. At the Planet Money website, you can see some really startling graphs and charts that tell this story in a way that you really can't tell a story on the radio. Seriously, some of these are kind of amazing. That is at planetmoney.com.

ep-491.act_title: Prologue
ep-491.speaker: ira glass
ep-491.utterance: This guy I know, David Rudis, was talking to me on the phone last week. He wanted me to help out with this Jewish organization that he's part of. David is concerned about the fact that fewer and fewer Jews are joining Jewish organizations and identifying as Jews. He thinks those organizations need to make themselves more relevant to modern Jews.

ep-491.act_title: Prologue
ep-491.speaker: ira glass
ep-491.utterance: And I was telling him, that's fine for him, but that is just not my thing. Yes, I'm Jewish, but I don't believe in God. I married a non-Jew. I've been eating bread all this week during Passover. I have plenty of interesting Jews in my life and feel no need to meet any more. Why would I ever join a Jewish organization?

ep-491.act_title: Prologue
ep-491.speaker: ira glass
ep-491.utterance: This, of course, led to the brief obligatory discussion of the Holocaust, which is what we Jews always talk about at a point like this in a conversation like this. And David was very insistent that it doesn't matter if I think of myself as a Jew. I just am a Jew.

ep-491.act_title: Prologue
ep-491.speaker: david rudis
ep-491.utterance: I think, Ira, you don't even begin to realize how much this identity has affected your life. As an avid listener to your show, there is something profoundly Jewish in the contents of what you're producing, whether you know it or not.

ep-491.act_title: Prologue
ep-491.speaker: ira glass
ep-491.utterance: I'm so surprised to hear you say that you think of the show as a Jewish kind of cultural product, because I don't think of it that way at all.

ep-491.act_title: Prologue
ep-491.speaker: david rudis
ep-491.utterance: See, I actually think it is. If you're playing morality plays to get into the hearts and heads of people on a weekly basis, what is more Jewish than that, than telling and interpreting a story? It's in your DNA.

ep-491.act_title: Prologue
ep-491.speaker: ira glass
ep-491.utterance: I suggested to him that telling stories is kind of something that every culture does, not just the Jews. David says sure, but so what?

ep-491.act_title: Prologue
ep-491.speaker: david rudis
ep-491.utterance: Literally what you're doing really is profoundly Jewish.

ep-491.act_title: Prologue
ep-491.speaker: ira glass
ep-491.utterance: It was a weird conversation. David thinks that in our big, multicultural world, of course it is just old-fashioned for people to identify strictly with their own ethnic tribe. He told me that he remembered when he first moved to Chicago decades ago, it was standard back then for people to just meet you and ask what are you? Meaning, what neighborhood are you from? What parish? What religion?

ep-491.act_title: Prologue
ep-491.speaker: ira glass
ep-491.utterance: It seemed really weird to him at the time. But at that same time as he was saying this he says-- no contradiction here-- he just likes having his own tribe and would like me to come join the herd.

ep-491.act_title: Prologue
ep-491.speaker: ira glass
ep-491.utterance: There's a scientist at UCLA named Jared Diamond, who came out recently with this book called The World Until Yesterday that's about how humans lived on this planet until about 10,000 years ago. When everybody lived, literally, in a tribe of a few hundred people, or a small band of a few dozen people. And Jared Diamond writes this thing about life then, about what it means to actually live in a tribe, that I had never heard before that really just stuck with me.

ep-491.act_title: Prologue
ep-491.speaker: ira glass
ep-491.utterance: He says that in these societies, because they were so small, you knew everybody. You never encountered strangers. You never ran into them.

ep-491.act_title: Prologue
ep-491.speaker: jared diamond
ep-491.utterance: The idea that you could just wander around and meet someone is utterly impossible in New Guinea. If you ran across a strange person on your land, that could only mean that they were there for some bad reason. They were there to scout out your land for a raid, or to steal a woman, or to steal a pig.

ep-491.act_title: Prologue
ep-491.speaker: jared diamond
ep-491.utterance: And so if you ran into a strange person in the forest and you couldn't run away from him, you came around a corner and there he was, then the two of you would sit down. And you'd have a long conversation in which each of you names all your relatives, trying to find some relative in common which gives you a reason not to kill each other. And if after two hours you haven't found any relative in common, then one of you starts running or you try to kill the other person.

ep-491.act_title: Prologue
ep-491.speaker: ira glass
ep-491.utterance: Diamond talked to me on the phone from Jakarta. He had just gotten there. Back to electricity and showers after three weeks off the grid in Papua, New Guinea.

ep-491.act_title: Prologue
ep-491.speaker: ira glass
ep-491.utterance: I wanted to speak with him, because I wondered what he thought this story meant. Was he saying, OK, this is who we are? This is just built into us to be suspicious and fearful of outsiders? To want to stick to our own tribe?

ep-491.act_title: Prologue
ep-491.speaker: jared diamond
ep-491.utterance: It's going too far to do that. People can be more or less suspicious of strangers, and it depends upon the circumstance.

ep-491.act_title: Prologue
ep-491.speaker: ira glass
ep-491.utterance: And so he says, for instance, the circumstances when humans lived in small traditional societies, there was good reason to fear strangers. As soon as human societies grew bigger, into groups of thousands of people, you'd run into strangers all the time. It was normal. You wouldn't have these same reasons to fear strangers, and so we stopped in lots of places.

ep-491.act_title: Prologue
ep-491.speaker: ira glass
ep-491.utterance: Though apropos of my conversation with David Rudis, Jared Diamond said that one of the things that does seem to have been true of traditional small societies 10,000 years ago that is still true today is an obsession with who's in and who's out, and seeing that people stick with the rules.

ep-491.act_title: Prologue
ep-491.speaker: jared diamond
ep-491.utterance: It's whenever there's a group, you have the problem of figuring out who really is a member of your group. And who is just pretending to be a member of the group for advantages. That may be part of the reason why humans have these very complicated cultures, including languages and body mutilation.

ep-491.act_title: Prologue
ep-491.speaker: jared diamond
ep-491.utterance: If I come into a group and I say, I'm really a long-lost member of your group but I can't speak your language and I haven't tattooed myself. Then it'll immediately be obvious that I'm not a member of your group. So all groups have what are called "expensive" ways of identifying themselves honestly so that you can't just fake it.

ep-491.act_title: Prologue
ep-491.speaker: ira glass
ep-491.utterance: Right. And the reason why it's so universal, is it just because if somebody can sneak in and be part of your group then they're getting access to stuff that's really yours?

ep-491.act_title: Prologue
ep-491.speaker: jared diamond
ep-491.utterance: That's right. The term is "freeloader."

ep-491.act_title: Prologue
ep-491.speaker: ira glass
ep-491.utterance: [INAUDIBLE] he says that that is the actual scientific term. That's the one that anthropologists use-- "freeloader."

ep-491.act_title: Prologue
ep-491.speaker: ira glass
ep-491.utterance: Well today on our radio show, we hear very different kinds of groups struggle with this question, who's in and who's out. It's the question which, of course, over history has led to purges, witch hunts, factionalism, the assassination of Trotsky, the Spanish Inquisition. Nobody expects the Spanish Inquisition, right? Well, we probably should. It happens all the time.

ep-491.act_title: Prologue
ep-491.speaker: ira glass
ep-491.utterance: Today on our program we have three stories of three groups, including one whose defining characteristic is that they talk very evenly and softly. From WBEZ, Chicago, it's This American Life, distributed by Public Radio International. I'm Ira Glass. Stay with us.

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: ira glass
ep-491.utterance: Act One, I Know I Am, But What Are You?

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: ira glass
ep-491.utterance: This story is about a group arguing over that most basic thing that any group can fight over-- who should be a member. The group is an Indian tribe in California, the Chukchansi, in the middle of the state. Currently about 900 members. One of many small tribes in California, and the dispute has gotten pretty bitter. David Ferry explains just how far they've gone.

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: david ferry
ep-491.utterance: Here's how bad things have gotten with the Chukchansi. About a year ago they had an election for their tribal government-- it's called the tribal council. Four people won majorities, but the old counsel refused to step down. They disqualified the winners and changed the locks on the tribe's equivalent of City Hall, which is actually a trailer like you'd see on a construction site, but a little bigger.

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: david ferry
ep-491.utterance: So two dozen tribal members who wanted the candidates they voted in to actually take office decided to go to City Hall, the trailer, early one morning and occupy the building.

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: woman 1
ep-491.utterance: Here we go. Here we go. Here we go. Here we go. Here we go.

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: david ferry
ep-491.utterance: This is from video taken by one of the occupiers of the building. It was meant to be a peaceful takeover, although they did break a window to get inside. They made coffee, ordered pizza and walked around the trailer with homemade signs. But loyalists of the incumbents, the counsel that refused to step down, started showing up. They were angry.

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: man 1
ep-491.utterance: Easy. Hey, calm down. Calm down.

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: man 2
ep-491.utterance: Dude, what about that [INAUDIBLE]?

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: man 2
ep-491.utterance: Get back in there.

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: man 1
ep-491.utterance: Calm down, you guys. [BLEEP]

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: david ferry
ep-491.utterance: One of the winning candidates who wasn't allowed to take her seat is Dixie Jackson. She was inside the trailer for the occupation. She thought she heard a gunshot at one point.

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: dixie jackson
ep-491.utterance: I said hit it, and I went down and hit the floor. Well then, I couldn't get up because, of course, I got a bad hip and bad knees.

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: david ferry
ep-491.utterance: Dixie's in her 70s. Here's Morris Read, another winner, also in his 70s.

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: morris read
ep-491.utterance: Once they broke the windows, they started spraying in that pepper spray. And we started to have a hard time breathing. And then all of a sudden they're throwing in burning logs. I think there was two of them that they threw through the window. And our people get wet rags and papers where we could put over our mouths so we could breathe.

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: dixie jackson
ep-491.utterance: We're not walking out! You were voted out by 150! Walk away! You walk away!

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: david ferry
ep-491.utterance: By nighttime, the occupation had turned into a siege. A crowd of 50 people outside cut off the power to the building, and then the water. They shot more pepper spray down into the ventilation system. Dixie and Morris and the other elders crowded into a tiny bathroom in the middle of the trailer for safety.

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: david ferry
ep-491.utterance: Someone called the cops and they showed up-- sheriffs from Fresno and Madera County, and the California Highway Patrol. But they couldn't intervene, because this was an internal tribal matter. By morning, 40 people were fist fighting in the parking lot outside the trailer. Local TV crews captured the tail end of it.

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: newswoman
ep-491.utterance: In the midst of the madness, one teenager was stabbed and two people were injured.

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: man 3
ep-491.utterance: All your people are going to [BLEEP] prison for this, too.

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: newswoman
ep-491.utterance: Two people were taken into custody. As for what caused the fighting--

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: david ferry
ep-491.utterance: This failed occupation, the election fiasco, it's all about one thing-- something called "disenrollment." That's the word Indians use for kicking someone out of the tribe. They get disenrolled.

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: david ferry
ep-491.utterance: For years now, the Chukchansi tribe has been disenrolling its own members-- dozens, sometimes hundreds of people at a time. The tribal members who occupy the trailer, the winners of the election, they wanted to stop the disenrollments-- the people outside didn't. Lots of tribes in California are disenrolling people, but the Chukchansi are sort of a poster tribe for it. Best estimates have the tribe shrinking from about 1,800 people, down to about 900.

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: david ferry
ep-491.utterance: So the tribe has cut itself in half, and almost all this has happened since they opened a casino. A big, shiny Casino with a spa, and a hotel, and a high roller club, 10 years ago in 2003.

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: male announcer
ep-491.utterance: At the foot of beautiful Yosemite Valley, there's a sound.

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: female singers
ep-491.utterance: Cha-ching!

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: david ferry
ep-491.utterance: This is one of their ads.

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: male announcer
ep-491.utterance: Can you hear it? The sound of winning.

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: male singer
ep-491.utterance: Let me hear that cha-ching!

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: male announcer
ep-491.utterance: Oh yeah, Chukchansi Gold Resort and Casino.

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: male singer
ep-491.utterance: The sweet sound of cha-ching!

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: david ferry
ep-491.utterance: The math is simple. If they have fewer people in the tribe, each person gets more of the sweet sound of cha-ching-- more profit from the casino. Right now each Chukchansi only gets a few hundred dollars a month in casino profits. A tribal member named Nicki Livingston told me that when her friend Nancy was kicked out a few months ago, she could see it in her payout check.

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: nicki livingston
ep-491.utterance: We got a raise on our per capita check after she got disenrolled.

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: david ferry
ep-491.utterance: You got more money per month after your close friend was disenrolled from the tribe?

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: nicki livingston
ep-491.utterance: Yeah. Me and my sisters, my two older sisters and myself, we were together when we heard that news. And we saw it [INAUDIBLE] saw it on our bank statements, and all three of us cried. It's done off the skin of someone's back.

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: david ferry
ep-491.utterance: She says the checks were around $280 per month before Nancy and several dozen other people were kicked out. She says it jumped about $380 a month after. There's another tribe just down the road from the Chukchansi, and its paid tens of thousands of dollars a month to each member. And that's because their tribe only has around 75 people.

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: david ferry
ep-491.utterance: Chukchansi officials usually deny that disenrollment has anything to do with casino money. They say all they're doing is correcting the membership rolls. Getting rid of the people who don't belong in the tribe. But Reggie Lewis, the tribal chairman who refused to step down when he was voted out of office, said to me, sure money has something to do with disenrollments, but why shouldn't it?

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: reggie lewis
ep-491.utterance: We don't have that much to share. We've got tribal members who are living in gutted out trailers with no sanitary facilities, without power. And then we have people who are trying to take advantage of being a tribal member when they're not entitled to be in.

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: david ferry
ep-491.utterance: This is the sound of my producer putting the microphone away as we're talking to a Chukchansi woman who'd agreed to be interviewed, but was so worried about repercussions that she kept going off the record or going silent. By the time I got to her, I was used to this. So many Chukchansi refused to talk, or agreed but then backed out saying that they were too scared. I asked this woman, who didn't want her name used, what people are scared of.

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: woman 2
ep-491.utterance: In my opinion, most of them are afraid because they either have members, loved ones or themselves that are employed.

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: david ferry
ep-491.utterance: How many people do you think you know who've been fired from the casino?

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: david ferry
ep-491.utterance: What's happening in the silence after my question is she's pointing at the microphone and shaking her head no. This woman had already been disenrolled, and she still didn't want to talk. She has family members who work at the casino. And like everyone else we met like that, she took it as a given, rightly or wrongly, that they might be fired if she spoke out.

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: david ferry
ep-491.utterance: The tribal council appoints the people who oversee the casino. There aren't a lot of jobs in this part of California. And the tribal council's very powerful-- in the community, and in the casino.

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: david ferry
ep-491.utterance: Disenrollment could mean serious financial hardship. When you're part of the tribe, you get a bunch of services. So on top of losing the monthly casino payout, people who are disenrolled also lose subsidies for child care and housing. Older members lose more-- a $300 monthly food stipend and extra cash to cover utilities. So no surprise there's now this culture of paranoia in the tribe. The anti-disenrollment folks are sure that some people who seem to be on their side are really spies for the other side.

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: david ferry
ep-491.utterance: I was talking to Morris Reed and Dixie Jackson, the ones who were elected to the tribal council but never seated. They're the ones who hid in the trailer choking on pepper spray. And Dixie said that at one point they tried to get tribal members to sign a petition supporting them, calling for an end to disenrollment. She said it went nowhere.

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: dixie jackson
ep-491.utterance: Even our own family says that they don't want to sign. Because then their names will be on the list that we support you, and therefore we will be subject to retaliation.

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: david ferry
ep-491.utterance: Dixie said one of her daughters had been fired from the casino two weeks earlier. She suspected it was retaliation against her family for occupying the trailer and opposing the tribal council. A casino spokesman told me the firing was not political.

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: david ferry
ep-491.utterance: As Dixie was telling me about all this, the phone rang. We were sitting around Morris's kitchen table. Morris answered it, and it was actually for Dixie.

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: morris reed
ep-491.utterance: Yes, she is. Do you want to talk to her? Somebody wants to talk to you.

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: dixie jackson
ep-491.utterance: Yes? Yes.

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: david ferry
ep-491.utterance: Dixie didn't talk long. It was about another daughter who still worked at the casino.

ep-491.speaker: dixie jackson
ep-491.utterance: They walked the other one out today.

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: david ferry
ep-491.utterance: Wait.

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: dixie jackson
ep-491.utterance: Just now.

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: david ferry
ep-491.utterance: Wait.

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: woman 3
ep-491.utterance: Wait, what?

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: dixie jackson
ep-491.utterance: They walked my daughter, the other daughter that was director of floor games.

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: morris reed
ep-491.utterance: OK, yes.

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?

ep-491.speaker: david ferry
ep-491.utterance: Bryan Galt saw how the disenrollments got started, and he's one of the few who saw it from the inside. But it was where the tribe stored all of its documents on everybody's ancestry. Before the casino was built, you just needed a birth certificate and some proof that you're a lineal descendant of a Chukchansi.

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: bryan galt
ep-491.utterance: I don't think you can imagine a more messed up filing system. Because it had been years of just people just shoving stuff in the files.

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: david ferry
ep-491.utterance: You were there though. Was the enrollment committee about letting people in, or was it about kicking people out?

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: bryan galt
ep-491.utterance: Well initially it was to help straighten out the records because they in such disarray. And then the casino opened, and then it started to become a head hunting expedition. Find out how people can be disenrolled.

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: david ferry
ep-491.utterance: Bryan says that mandate came from the top, the tribal council, but he didn't agree with it.

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: bryan galt
ep-491.utterance: My committee, we refused to take action against anyone who was already enrolled because we didn't think it was fair. They're enrolled-- just leave it at that.

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: bryan galt

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: bryan galt
ep-491.utterance: There was no Dances With Wolves type mentality. I hate that movie for that reason. They show the wise old tribal chief, you know, that's all I have to say, and everyone's polite to each other through the whole meeting. ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: david ferry
ep-491.utterance: This is a small tribe, remember. Everyone knows everybody else. And everyone thinks they know who's pushing to disenroll people.

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: david ferry
ep-491.utterance: There's a family called the Wyatts, and there's another called the Ramirezes. ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: david ferry
ep-491.utterance: One person who's supported disenrollment for years is Reggie Lewis. He's the tribal leader you heard from earlier who refused to step down after the election. He says the disenrollments are necessary because of the weird history of the tribe. The Federal government disbanded them in 1958, along with lots of other California tribes. And when they started up again in the 1980s, he says they were in a rush. That they didn't really know what they were doing.

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: reggie lewis
ep-491.utterance: For a long time, our tribe was looked that as kind of a joke as far as membership. Because they were saying oh yeah, the Chukchansi tribe, that's a country club. You can go up and join. They just knew that they could get in.

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: david ferry
ep-491.utterance: And so he says they had to make a lot of hard choices. He told me he even voted to disenroll his own cousins-- he had to.

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: reggie lewis
ep-491.utterance: They are my cousins, but they didn't have any Chukchansi in them. For years they thought that they were Chukchansi. We thought they were Chukchansi. When the research was done, we find out that no, they were not even Indians. They were white people.

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: david ferry
ep-491.utterance: The fact is, even tribes that aren't disenrolling people have a hard time figuring out how to decide who's in the tribe. What's important-- blood line? DNA? Language? Land ownership?

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: david ferry
ep-491.utterance: In California, tribes were hunted down and forced to disband. To abandon their land and their language. There was lots of intermarriage. Records were lost. It's a mess.

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: david ferry
ep-491.utterance: So the Chukchansi settled on a set of arcane rules based on land ownership and ancestry to determine who could stay in their tribe. If your family had Chukchansi ancestry but no one got a land grant from the Federal government long ago, you were given a one-year deadline to get in your paperwork. If you didn't make the deadline or the extension, you were disenrolled. If you're one of the luckier families that was deeded land, for you there's no deadline. But your ancestry gets combed over and scrutinized for any hint of non-Chukchansiness.

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: irene cordero
ep-491.utterance: This is the letter I got right here.

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: david ferry

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: irene cordero

ep-491.speaker: david ferry

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: irene cordero
ep-491.utterance: She'll be 90 in January.

ep-491.speaker: david ferry

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: irene cordero
ep-491.utterance: Uh huh.

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: irene cordero
ep-491.utterance: About two.

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: david ferry

ep-491.speaker: david ferry
ep-491.utterance: Disenrollment letters all end with a line saying the tribal council's decisions are final and not appeal-able to any state or federal court. There's nowhere to go to say but wait, this woman speaks Chukchansi. Doesn't that count somehow? Irene can't take this to the US courts or the Bureau of Indian Affairs and expect any help, because each tribe operates like it's own separate country. And for the Chukchansi, the tribal council's the final authority.

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: david ferry
ep-491.utterance: A few months after the tribe disenrolled Irene's mother Ruby, one of the last remaining native speakers, they gave a million dollars to a local university for the study and revitalization of the Chukchansi language.

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?

ep-491.speaker: david ferry
ep-491.utterance: The same day Bryan found out he'd been disenrolled, he lost his job as a beverage manager and web director for the casino. The casino spokesman told me the firing had nothing to do with his disenrollment.

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: david ferry
ep-491.utterance: Tribes across the country are watching these mass disenrollments by the Chukchansi and others, and they're just flabbergasted. Here's David Wilkins. He's a Lumbee Indian, and a professor of American Indian studies at the University of Minnesota.

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: david wilkins
ep-491.utterance: I get shocked every time I read any Country Today and see that another tribe, usually it's out of California, that has decided that they're going to disenroll another 22 families.

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: david ferry
ep-491.utterance: Wilkins is one of the few people who studies disenrollment.

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: david wilkins
ep-491.utterance: Disenrollment is occurring now in some 17 states. It's occurring in at least 30 tribes in California. I can't find a definitive number on how many native individuals have formally been disenrolled.

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: david wilkins
ep-491.utterance: I see figures ranging 4,000 to 6,000. But it's difficult to find accurate data because, like I say, tribal governments are not going to be forthcoming with this information. The Bureau of Indian Affairs refuses to share this information because they say that it's a tribal internal matter. And so as a scholar, as a researcher, I'm frustrated and embittered because I can't find the accurate data to get the word out about what we're doing to ourselves.

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: david ferry
ep-491.utterance: Wilkins told me other tribes are watching the Chukchansi and others disenroll their members with no consequences and so they're trying it, too. And he said something that I'd heard from a lot of Indians. We were almost wiped out by other people. And why are we now whittling ourselves away through disenrollments?

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: david wilkins
ep-491.utterance: And this is what I find most frustrating when I have to say that we really are involved in depopulating ourselves. And at this point we can't blame the Federal government, we can't blame the state that we're in. We have to look at ourselves in the mirror and try and explain this to ourselves.

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: david ferry
ep-491.utterance: With the Chukchansi, a lot of the tribe's members thought disenrollment was OK as long as it was happening to other people. They never thought it would happen to them, so they didn't stand up against it. Even the current opponents of disenrollment, the four people elected to the tribal council who never got a chance to take their seat, they used to sit on the council years ago. And when they did, they presided over hundreds of disenrollments themselves.

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: david ferry
ep-491.utterance: At this point, no one feels safe. Even Reggie Lewis, the tribal chairman who refused to give up his seat in the election. Even he can imagine a future council trying to kick him out.

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: reggie lewis
ep-491.utterance: The reason will be whatever they want to say, because they will be the ultimate say so. It doesn't matter what is right or what is wrong. I have the documentation to show that I am from this area. I have established a special relationship with people that are in the Wyatt and Ramirez family.

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: david ferry
ep-491.utterance: He's talking about the two families in the tribe that folks say are staunch supporters of disenrollment-- the Wyatts and the Ramirezes.

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: reggie lewis
ep-491.utterance: I cut timber for 40 years and I got Mike Ramirez jobs. I worked with Mike. His father used to come up and get drunk with my father. I went over and had beers with his father and my father.

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: reggie lewis
ep-491.utterance: His sister was married to one of my cousins. And they lived right next door to me on my allotment on top of the hill here in Coarsegold. ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: david ferry
ep-491.utterance: Meanwhile at the casino, things aren't looking too good. Another tribe is planning to build a competing casino just 30 miles down the road. And Reggie Lewis told me the Chukchansi casino is still $250 million in debt from its construction.

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: david ferry
ep-491.utterance: About a year and a half ago, it missed a payment on that debt. He says they might miss another this month. He told me that if they do miss that payment, members of the tribe might not get their payouts or benefits.

ep-491.act_title: Act One: I Know I Am, But What Are You?
ep-491.speaker: david ferry
ep-491.utterance: The tribe has gone through all this heartache. It's on track to disenroll the majority of its members. If the point was to generate a higher payout for everyone who remained, that might not be panning out.

ep-491.speaker: ira glass

ep-491.act_title: Act Two: A Tribe Called Rest
ep-491.speaker: ira glass
ep-491.utterance: Act Two, A Tribe Called Rest.

ep-491.act_title: Act Two: A Tribe Called Rest
ep-491.speaker: ira glass
ep-491.utterance: You know, sometimes it can be easy to believe that you are in a tribe of one-- alone there by yourself. Andrea Seigel tells this story about finding out that she is undeniably not alone.

ep-491.act_title: Act Two: A Tribe Called Rest
ep-491.speaker: andrea seigel
ep-491.utterance: In the fourth grade, I had this one friend Mindy. She was OK to hang out with and all. But what was really great about her was that she would always want to see whatever stuff I had in my room. If I sat her down in front of my shell collection, she would delicately go through it one shell at a time. She'd murmur to herself what she liked about each shell, and I'd get this tingling throughout my skull.

ep-491.act_title: Act Two: A Tribe Called Rest
ep-491.speaker: andrea seigel
ep-491.utterance: I know how weird that sounds. But it was like starbursts in my head. Starbursts that open on the crown and then sparkle down at the nape like this warm, glittering water rushing under your scalp.

ep-491.act_title: Act Two: A Tribe Called Rest
ep-491.speaker: andrea seigel
ep-491.utterance: I'd seek this feeling out, starting when I was seven. I'd go to the library so I could sit in a big, quiet room, and listen to pages being turned. There was a boring librarian who everyone in fifth grade hated. But I loved her, because when she would read us stories in her soft voice, she'd turn my head into a snow globe.

ep-491.act_title: Act Two: A Tribe Called Rest
ep-491.speaker: andrea seigel
ep-491.utterance: I was an anxious kid. I worried about getting homework finished, even back when homework didn't count for anything. But while I was getting this tingling in my head, my anxiety just magically fell away. And afterward, I'd actually feel kind of good for a half hour.

ep-491.act_title: Act Two: A Tribe Called Rest
ep-491.speaker: andrea seigel
ep-491.utterance: Then I found this public access lady on TV who used to show you how to stencil flowers on a wall. She gave me the tingling. I'd also get it watching the late, great Bob Ross teach how to paint mountains on PBS.

ep-491.act_title: Act Two: A Tribe Called Rest
ep-491.speaker: bob ross
ep-491.utterance: So we have black, blue, crimson, little bit of brown. Now then, barely touch the canvas.

ep-491.act_title: Act Two: A Tribe Called Rest
ep-491.speaker: andrea seigel
ep-491.utterance: So there's Bob Ross. And I'm eight and sitting on the carpet in the den, watching him delicately mix paint colors in close up. And I am going into a trance. My jaw kind of goes slack. My eyes are probably a little glassy. And my head is a globe.

ep-491.act_title: Act Two: A Tribe Called Rest
ep-491.speaker: bob ross
ep-491.utterance: Take a little blue and white here-- just mix it together. And once again, flap our little tiny roll of paint.

ep-491.act_title: Act Two: A Tribe Called Rest
ep-491.speaker: andrea seigel
ep-491.utterance: So as I grew up, I never told my parents about this. Never talked to anybody. I assumed the tingling was an almost pervy way I was miswired. I felt ashamed about it, and all I understood was that I didn't want anyone to know.

ep-491.act_title: Act Two: A Tribe Called Rest
ep-491.speaker: andrea seigel
ep-491.utterance: It became even more extreme as an adult. As a kid I was only allowed to watch a certain amount of television. But once I was old enough to own my own TV, I would stay up until 4:00 AM watching home shopping network night after night. Soft-spoken women talked about the jewelry in very detailed, intricate, precious ways, and I loved it. People were confused about why I watched so much home shopping, because I never bought anything.

ep-491.act_title: Act Two: A Tribe Called Rest
ep-491.speaker: andrea seigel
ep-491.utterance: But the starbursts worked as well as an adult as they had as a kid. They calm my anxiety. And calming is important, because I'm still an anxious person. In fact, I'm way worse as an adult-- there's a lot more to be anxious about.

ep-491.act_title: Act Two: A Tribe Called Rest
ep-491.speaker: andrea seigel
ep-491.utterance: And I still never told anyone about what was going on inside my head, not even my boyfriend Brent. We've been together for years. We have a kid together. We tell each other everything. I've told him some really horrible, embarrassing things about myself, but I didn't tell him this. Like, I would never turn to him during dinner and ask, so when the fork just delicately pinged against the knife, did you get tingles throughout your brain, too?

ep-491.act_title: Act Two: A Tribe Called Rest
ep-491.speaker: andrea seigel
ep-491.utterance: A few years ago, I started seeking out this stuff on YouTube. I began with makeup tutorials, because I love to hear the tapping of a brush on a Mac pigment bottle, or the clicking up of an eyeliner pencil. That's how I moved on to this woman named Senada, who does something called haul videos, that's H-A-U-L, which are just her talking about what she bought on a shopping trip. These kind of videos are actually really popular-- there are tons of them.

ep-491.act_title: Act Two: A Tribe Called Rest
ep-491.speaker: senada
ep-491.utterance: Hi, everyone. Welcome back to my channel. Today I wanted to show you what I got from the Versace for H&M. So as you can see I have--

ep-491.act_title: Act Two: A Tribe Called Rest
ep-491.speaker: andrea seigel
ep-491.utterance: So I was up to watching two or three hours a day. And I know this is all starting to sound like porn and someone's obsession with porn. But it's not porn, even if it does operate a little bit like porn. All the searching for videos, trying to find exactly the right moment or performer, developing very specific tastes and preferences.

ep-491.act_title: Act Two: A Tribe Called Rest
ep-491.speaker: andrea seigel
ep-491.utterance: I wanted someone speaking in lightly accented English. And I wanted them talking to me about jewelry, slowly and deliberately. And preferably, it's tacky or cheap jewelry that isn't being treated as if it's tacky and cheap. And just like porn, the effect wears off after a while. You have to find new videos.

ep-491.act_title: Act Two: A Tribe Called Rest
ep-491.speaker: andrea seigel
ep-491.utterance: Finally one night over the recent holidays, I was suddenly out of videos. I'd exhausted all my usual haul favorites. Despairing, I typed jewelry collection into the search box. Nothing I hadn't seen already.

ep-491.act_title: Act Two: A Tribe Called Rest
ep-491.speaker: andrea seigel
ep-491.utterance: That was when I had an idea. I'd noticed a number of the haulers on YouTube who had accented English had trouble with the spelling of jewelry. I typed in jewelry again, this time with two Ls.

ep-491.act_title: Act Two: A Tribe Called Rest
ep-491.speaker: andrea seigel
ep-491.utterance: YouTube returned a video at the top of the search entitled ASMR, Old Jewelry Collection, Show and Tell Whisperer. It was made by YouTuber called--

ep-491.act_title: Act Two: A Tribe Called Rest
ep-491.speaker: thewaterwhispers ilse
ep-491.utterance: TheWaterwhispers Ilse.

ep-491.act_title: Act Two: A Tribe Called Rest
ep-491.speaker: andrea seigel
ep-491.utterance: That was TheWaterwhispers Ilse. On the screen, a woman smiled and waved and then she began.

ep-491.act_title: Act Two: A Tribe Called Rest
ep-491.speaker: thewaterwhispers ilse
ep-491.utterance: Hey guys, today I'm at my grandpa's house and I'm going to share something personal with you guys. It's kind of a show and tell video, because I'm going to show you the jewelry-- I always struggle with that word.

ep-491.act_title: Act Two: A Tribe Called Rest
ep-491.speaker: andrea seigel
ep-491.utterance: I was like, what the hell is this? I kept watching.

ep-491.act_title: Act Two: A Tribe Called Rest
ep-491.speaker: thewaterwhispers ilse
ep-491.utterance: I'm going to show you the jewelry of my grandma. She passed away in 2008. And she was actually, together with Bob Ross, one of the first people who gave me ASMR when I was a kid.

ep-491.act_title: Act Two: A Tribe Called Rest
ep-491.speaker: andrea seigel
ep-491.utterance: I was stunned. I mean, I was loving this video. But also, one, I was shocked by the Bob Ross mention. ep-491.act_title: Act Two: A Tribe Called Rest
ep-491.speaker: andrea seigel
ep-491.utterance: So I googled ASMR, which led me knowyourmeme.com.
